metadata.title: Diffusion tensor imaging based white matter changes and antioxidant enzymes status for early identification of mild cognitive impairment
metadata.abstract: Mild cognitive impairment (MCI) is an early stage of dementia. The changes in white matter integrity and antioxidant enzymes levels are crucial in onset and progression to Alzheimers disease (AD). To elucidate the changes in cognitive performance, white matter integrity, oxidative stress marker, for early detection of prodromal state of AD. Fifty cases of MCI and controls (55-75 years) were subjected to Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE), diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) followed by estimation of superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, and lipid peroxidation in serum of MCI and control population. The MMSE scores of MCI subjects were (28  2-22.6  1) as compared with controls (28  1-29  1). DTI metrics fractional anisotropy (FA) values in right and left frontal lobe, fornix, corpus callosum, while apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) values in right temporal lobe, hippocampus head, corpus callosum right, and forcep major were significantly altered in MCI as compared with controls. Superoxide dismutase and glutathione peroxidase levels were lower while lipid peroxidation marker malondialdehyde (MDA) was increased in patients with MCI as compared with controls. The study emphasized that changes in neuro-psychological performance, white matter integrity, and antioxidant enzymes level provide early signature for diagnosis of MCI.

Introduction.text: Alzheimers dementia (AD) is normally preceded by a period of mild cognitive impairment (MCI). MCI can be defined as the transitional state between healthy aging and very mild Alzheimers disease, and therefore, it has become a focal point for clinical research 1,2. Although, MCI can be presented with multiple symptoms but memory complaint is one of the predominant symptoms, and addressed as amnestic MCI (aMCI). The average rate of conversion of these MCI subject to probably AD is about 10-15 as compared with 1-2 of normal aging individuals 3. White matter (WM) change may complement grey matter as evident by study that combination of diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) and cortical thickness has higher sensitivity and specificity to differentiate amnestic MCI from healthy control 4. The recent finding on WM damage in AD postmortem tissues, WM signal abnormalities, and volumetric reduction in MRI findings provide strong rational for understanding WM changes in AD 4567. The common measurement of DTI is overall assessment of diffusivity of water molecules, through diffusion tensor and is known as apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC), while anisotropy is calculated by fractional anisotropy (FA) 8,9. Therefore, it is an important neuroimaging tool employed for detail investigation of the microstructures and integrity of WM fiber tracts 8,9. The FA and ADC values of DTI in neurological disorder are influenced by various factors such as myelination, axon density, axonal membrane integrity, axonal diameter and intravoxel coherence of fiber orientation 10,11. The clinical progression of MCI to AD can be specifically delineated by study of WM changes as evident by results of various studies 10,11. There is great interest in identification of predictors of dementia in people with MCI, because some people with MCI progress to dementia but others remain stable or recover full function 12. The preliminary screening of elderly population can be done through Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) best known screening tool for overall assessment of cognitive impairment in clinical, research, and community setting 12. The role of oxidative stress in AD pathogenesis is well established 13. The oxidative stress begin early in progression of AD and provide potential target for therapeutic and biomarker identification 14. The accumulation of product of free radical damage in tissues of central and peripheral nervous system of AD and MCI subject was already reported 15,16. The status of various antioxidant enzymes like glutathione peroxidase (GPX), glutathione-S-tranferase (GST), and superoxide dismutase (SOD) has been found to be downregulated while marker of lipid peroxidation malondialdehyde are found to be elevated in AD subjects 14,17. Therefore, the aim of the current study was to investigate changes in cognitive performance, WM integrity, antioxidant enzymes, and lipid peroxidation level in serum of elderly population for early identification of MCI subjects (Table 1).

Subject enrollment.text: A case control study was performed in S.S.Hospital, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi from June 2015 to March 2017 after Ethical approval from Institutes Ethics Committee of Institute of Medical Sciences, Banaras Hindu University, Varanasi, India. Fifty cases, between age group of (55-75 years) of either gender, were selected after taking informed consent. The inclusion criteria study included patients with MCI, mainly amnestic individuals reported to our hospital with memory complaint andor other cognitive problem from care giver for more than 6 months with no previous history of any systemic and vascular problems. Other inclusion criteria included patients who can speak HindiEnglish, and with stable and controlled medical conditions such as hypertension, diabetes mellitus, and hyperlipidemia. Exclusion criteria included subjects with neurological diseases such as stroke, severe small vessel disease, and other systemic problem. All cases were subjected to routine clinical interview and completed neuropsychological tests at baseline and follow-up after 6 months at our outpatient clinic. MCI was diagnosed according to criteria of Petersen and coworkers 1,2. Further, all MCI subjects had complaint of subjective memory over last 6 months and had Clinical Dementia Rating Scale (CDR) score of 0.5, and impaired memory function (verbal of figural) in neuropsychological assessment -1.5 standard deviation (SD) related to age and education. Fifty healthy age matched controls were selected that did not meet the criteria for dementia and presented no cognitive complaints or performance below -1.5 SD on neuropsychological test. Blood was collected and allowed to clot after mild centrifugation, serum was collected and stored at -80 C for further use.

Diffusion tensor imaging.text: The DTI sequence utilized was a single-shot, balanced echoplannar imaging EPI sequence with timing parameters of TR 6000 ms and TE 97 ms. Twenty contiguous transverse slices with a slice thickness of 5 mm were aligned parallel to the anterior commissure and posterior commissure plane and covered all but the topmost part of the brain. The FOV was 128 Â 128 mm, acquisition matrix 96 Â 128, reconstructed to 128 Â 128, giving a reconstructed in-plane resolution of 1.78 mm Â 1.78 mm. For each slice, one image without diffusion weighting (b ¼ 0 smm 2 ) and six images with diffusion weighting (b0 ¼ 1000 smm 2 ) applied along six non-collinear directions were acquired. The six DTI acquisitions for each subject were registered using a mutual information cost function and a 12-parameter transformation with the first b ¼ 0 smm 2 volume reference.

Post-processing and analysis.text:
Data post-processing was done using the automated Neuro-3D software (Siemens Medical System) on the offline workstation. The image analysis was performed in presence of expert neurologist and Radiologist. The senior radiologists, however, evaluated and reported the DTI data prior to viewing the routine MR imaging, to exclude any kind of observer bias. The data were evaluated in two steps: First, a random eyeball evaluation of the DTI color maps RGB maps and the T1 weighted image map was done; second, a semi-quantitative evaluation of the same images was done to pre-identify areas of asymmetry of color saturation and hue. These were done for guiding and correlating
with the quantitative analysis, which was the final aim of this study. Finally, quantitative analysis of FA and ADC maps, generated automatically by the propriety software, was done by drawing region of interest (ROI) in the interactive maps, to include the WM tracts emanating from the most functionally active areas in the brain. The diameter of 3 mm was used for each ROI and an average of three consecutive values at the same point was registered.

SOD activity.text: The SOD activity was measured using SOD Assay Kit (Cat. No-19160, Mercks). In brief, the enzyme activity was measured as percentage reaction inhibition rate of enzymes with water soluble tetrazolium dye and xanthine oxidase after incubation of 20 min at 37 C, absorbance was measured at 450 nm. The percent inhibition was normalized by mg protein and presented as SOD activity unitmL.

GPX activity.text: The GPX activity was estimated using GPX Assay Kit (Cat. No-CGP-1, Merck). In brief, the enzymes activity was measured by decrease in NADPH at 340 nm during oxidation of NADPH to NADP. The kit is based on indirect method of oxidation of glutathione (GSH) to oxidized glutathione (GSSG) by GPX, which is then uses NADPH and glutathione reductase (GR) to convert GSSG to GSH. The enzyme activity was expressed in unitmL.

Lipid peroxidation.text: The thiobarbituric acid reactive substance (TBARS) assay was used to estimate malondialdehyde (MDA) level. In brief, 200 mL of serum was mixed with 50 of trichloroacetic acid with 0.9 mL of Tris-HCL (pH 7.4), 1 mL of 0.73 of thiobarbituric acid. After, vortex mixing, samples were kept at 100 C for 20 min. After centrifugation at 3000 rpm for 10 min, supernatant was isolated and absorbance was taken at 532 nm. The activity was calculated against the MDA standard curve and the results were expressed in nmolL 18.

Statistical analysis.text: The mean of all value calculated during MMSE and antioxidant enzymes level of each elderly healthy and MCI subjects were calculated. Further, the values of ADC and FA values were calculated and inter group comparison was done. The inter group comparison was done by using the non-parametric Mann-Whitney test using the SPSS software (SPSS version 17.0; SPSS, Chicago, IL, USA). p  0.05 was used as an indicator of significance.

Neuropsychological and demographic asses.text: The total of 50 individuals was identified suffering from MCI out of which 33 were male and 17 were females. Fifty cognitively healthy subjects with same age and sex were registered as control. The neuropsychological assessment was done through MMSE test found that cognitive scoring for age group 55-60 yr (male and female were 28  2 vs. 29  1 of control), 61-65 yr (male and female were 26.2  2 vs. 29  1 of control), 66-70 yr (male and female were 25  1 vs. 28  1 of control) 71-75 yr (male and female were 22.6  1 vs. 28  1 age match control). The decrease in MMSE score in older age group (61-75 yr as compared with 55-60 yr) directly associated with years of education and demographic location as depicted in Table 2.

Global evaluation.text: The measured variables were 44 through DTI imaging and compared with corresponding similar areas of controls. The overall analysis of 44 variables from 22 ROI. The variables like FA and ADC showed significant difference in MCI subject as compared with respective controls.

FA regional evaluation.text: The FA estimated in all 22 ROI had shown significant differences in right and left frontal lobe (p  0.001; 3 and Figure 1(A,B)).

ADC regional evaluation.text: The value of ADC evaluated at different WM regions of interest revealed that ADC value of right temporal lobe was significantly at higher side as compared with control (p  0.001), similarly hippocampus head was significantly higher in value as compared with control, corpus callosum right, and forcep major have higher ADC value as compared with respective controls (p  0.01) (Table 4 and Figure 1(A,B)).

SOD, GPX, and lipid peroxidation (MDA) l.text: The activity of SOD and GPX was significantly lower in MCI subjects as compared with control (p  0.05) (Figures 2 and3). The lipid peroxidation (MDA) level was significantly higher in MCI subjects (p  0.01) as compared with control (Figure 4).

Discussion.text:
The neuropsychological analysis of MCI subjects showed significant difference in orientation, immediate recall, attention, 3-step command, delayed recall, naming, reading and comprehension, writing, copy design, when assessed on MMSE test. The MMSE score of MCI subjects in age group 65-75 yr was less as compared with 55-60 yr age group, which might be due to lower number of education years and higher percentage of individuals from rural community (Table 2). The increase in cognitive dysfunction in older age group was in agreement with the previous study, where subjects 70 yr or above had higher subjective dysfunction on recent and past memories in comparison to 60-65 yr age group 19. Community-based studies had shown the association of education bias on cognitive performance that supports the findings of our study also indicates that lower number of education years decreases cognitive dysfunction 19. The changes in FA values in frontal lobe, forcep major, fornix, and corpus callosum regions of MCI subject directly influences the neuropsychological performance such as composite memory, long-term retrieval, free recall, abstract thinking, 3 step command functions of brains in MCI subjects as compared with age matched controls. The decrease in FA value in MCI subjects and its influences on neuropsychological performance has been well established in previous studies 20,21. The changes in memory and cognitive symptoms of MCI subjects in our study were mainly related to changes in microstructural WM damage. The study of Stricker et al. depicted that decrease in WM integrity was related to cognition and is independent of cortical thinning 22. The studies reported lower FA value in splenium of corpus callosum as compared with control 23,24. The decrease in FA value of fornix associated with corpus callosum of MCI subjects in the current study depicts the linkage of age associated decline in WM integrity. The changes in WM pattern were due to myelin degeneration, which might be variable in different regions of brain leading to age related difference in FA. In our study, we obtained similar decrease in FA value in regions of brain that mainly connect grey matter, degeneration of myelin in the respected regions of brain resulted in lowering of FA value and Studies have shown that the decrease of FA value in anterior-posterior gradient implies such brain areas which were highly myelinated are more susceptible for degeneration as observed in the current study 24. Although, study conducted by Sulvian et al. proposed that age-related decline in FA value were mainly prominent in centrum semiovale and corticospinal tract 25. Although, studies have proved that regions of brain which myelinate fully are most vulnerable to negative effect of aging, which might be due to oligodendrocytes of associative WM pathway where most active cells are prone to metabolic damage 26. There were different theories mainly anterior-posterior and superior-inferior gradient theory suggested that damage within WM pathways decreases the efficiency of communications among widely distributed neural system comprising cognition, which lead to a disconnection of cognitive network 2728293031. The increases in ADC value in elderly population in different brain regions have been well reported 323334. The increase in ADC value in our study in the regions of right temporal lobe, hippocampus head, corpus callosum right, and forcep major was significantly high in MCI subjects as compared with age matched control (Figure 1(A,B)). The increase in ADC value might be due to severe fiber degeneration that leads to decreased tract volume and increase isotropic diffusivity through partial volume effect of surrounding cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). The age-related increase in radial diffusivity (RD) is the signature of demyelination and is also represented in animal models 34353637. The changes in hippocampus volume are critical to episodic memory functions 38. The changes observed in ADC value of hippocampus head was in cohesion with the finding of Persson et al. in which the age-related episodic memory deficits were strongly correlated with WM alteration in hippocampal connections 39. The increase in ADC value of forcep major was mainly due to the loss of myelin which is consistent with histological findings of age-related loss of myelin and myelinated fibers in old age 404142. The loss of myelin and axon in corpus callosum increases the extracellular volume fraction and lower membrane density, which increases axonal spacing and reduced extracellular tortuosity 42,43. The contradictory results are available for variable level of antioxidant enzyme in neurodegenerative disorders 44. In this study, we observed decrease in SOD and GPX level in MCI individuals. SODs reduce molecular oxygen to hydrogen peroxide(H 2 O 2) produced at physiological level from respiratory chain 45. The decrease in SOD and GPX activity in MCI subject as compared with control might result in accumulation of H 2 O 2 , which react with lipid and protein resulting in cellular damage 46. The increase in lipid peroxidation in MCI subject in our study is in agreement with previous studies, showing progressive increase of MDA in MCI and AD 47. The decrease in antioxidant enzymes and increase in lipid peroxidation might play significant role in conversion of MCI subject to prodromal AD 47.
The findings of our study signifies that changes in cognitive functions, WM integrity and antioxidant enzyme level could provide very significant marker for early identification of MCI subjects which are at high risk of developing AD in near future.

Conclusion.text: The data from the present study signifies the potential of DTI technique in identifying the changes in WM cerebral integrity and cognitive performance of elderly population using standard verified neuropsychological tests. The decrease in peripheral antioxidant enzymes and increase in lipid peroxidation level in MCI subjects provide early evidence for neurodegeneration. The findings from this study provide preliminary signatures for identification of MCI subjects at high risk for development of AD.
